title: Open Data in Practice Day 1 - Practical Publication
displayTitle: Open Data in Practice Day 1 - Practical Publication
body: Welcome to the first session of Open Data in Practice. This course is your complete introduction to the practical skills of open data. Day 1 examines practical approaches to the publication of open data. To get started, look at the course overview below.

title: Course overview
body: The first day is split into three key sessions. The first session explores definitions of open data and key characteristics, the second takes a closer look at data publishing platforms and the last will get participants hands-on with publication.

_items.title: Characteristics of data
_items.body:
The session explores key definitions of open data.

The session also examines types of data to determine their uses.

_items.title: Data discovery patterns
_items.body:
This session looks and how and where people find data online. Understanding how people discover data is a key component of good publication and allows you to make your data more visible to users.

The session also explores different types of open data feed and looks at when it is appropriate to use them.

_items.title: Publishing platforms
_items.body: Making your open data available online can be a tricky process. To make it easier, a number of software platforms exist that simplify the process and save you time. This session looks at some of the most popular publishing platforms.

_items.title: Hands-on publishing
_items.body: This final session builds on everything you have learned throughout the day by challenging participants to publish their own dataset. The session will give participants hands-on experience of publishing and using popular data platforms.

title: What is open data?
body:
Open data is data that anyone can access, use and share.

Open data becomes useable through being available in a common, machine-readable format.

Open data must be licensed. This licence must permit people to use the data in any way they want, including transforming, combining and sharing it with others, even commercially.

title: Challenges of Open Data and Future Developments
displayTitle: Challenges of Open Data and Future Developments

title: Challenges of Open Data
body: Open data is still a developing field and faces a number of key challenges which need to be addressed. The following section outlines some of the key areas
instruction: Click below to explore each of the tools to unlock data that is on the web.

_items.title: Inconsistent definitions
_items.body:
Like any new field, open data needs a strong definition to give clarity around what it is and what you can do with it. While many definitions of open data currently exist, promoted by different organisations and meeting different needs, there is no consistency about the terms used in these definitions.

A recent study by GovLab has highlighted the number of different terms used when defining open data in a simple chart that illustrates the need for greater consistency.

_items.title: Lack of proper licences
_items.body:
The majority of datasets described as 'open' still do not have an appropriate licence to protect the ability of everyone to access, use and share them.

A lack of clarity and understanding on the differences between copyright and licences means that many open data sets are not properly licensed. This study by Thomas Levine reveals the extent of this problem.

In Tanzania, copyright laws are complex. While data might be intended to be open, a licence provides legal clarity for users.

The 1999 Copyright and Neighbouring Rights Act provides the legal clarity on the data protections in place.

_items.title: Failure to update consistently
_items.body: Simply publishing a dataset is not enough to ensure reuse and relaise the benefits of open data. Datasets also need to be updated at regular intervals to ensure they remain relevant and up-to-date. However, the vast majority of datasets are not updated consistently as shown by the graphics in this study by Thomas Levine.

_items.title: Not everything should be open
_items.body:
Some of us worry about personal health records being “made open”. Some confuse commercial and personal data, or mix up “big data” with “open data”.

To maximize data’s benefits, we first need to be precise about which type of data we are dealing with and the limitations of it's access.

Not all data should be openly availble to everyone to use freely, conversly applying a “closed by default” policy will minimize the opportunities that might come from even limited sharing.

To help explain this complicated landscape, the Open Data Institute has produced the data spectrum. The data spectrum is a handy tool to help you map out existing data holdings and help reveal future opportunities.

title: Marques of quality
body:
Marques of quality provide users with confidence to use a open dataset freely.

There are two key marques to look out for on open data:

_items.title: 5 Stars
_items.body:
The '5 Stars of linked open data' include the basic legal definition and technical excellence of the published data.

The 5 Stars were developed by inventor of the Web, Sir Tim Berners-Lee, in 2001. The 5 Stars make recommendations for the format and structure of the data.

You can learn more about the 5 Stars from the European data portal eLearning, module 10 covers the first 3 stars, module 13 covers the 4th and 5th star. There is also a more technical guide available.

_items.title: ODI Open Data Certificates
_items.body:
The Open Data Institute's Open Data Certificates are practical, social, legal and technical guidelines to consider when publishing or using open data.

The certificates act as a self-assessment questionnaire for publishers, and in some cases users, to assess and benchmark the full usability of a dataset.

Take me to the ODI Open Data Certificates site

title: What do ODI Certificates look for?
displayTitle: What do ODI Certificates look for?
body: Community-driven standards define the legal, practical, technical and social requirements for an open dataset to be useful.
instruction: Click the forward arrow to see more.Select the ‘+’ sign to explore further, then swipe the image to see more.

_items.title: Legal requirements
_items.body:
In addition to the open licence, there are three legal requirements that need to be considered. You must:

  • Protect sensitive information like personal data.
  • Preserve the rights of data owners.
  • Promote correct use of the data.

_items.title: Practical requirements
_items.body:
It is important that open data can be found and relied upon by users.

This means that open data publishers must:

  • Link to the data from their website.
  • Update the data regularly if it changes.
  • Commit to continue to make the data available.

_items.title: Technical requirements
_items.body:
There are three recommendations that define the technical aspects of open data:

  • The format in which the data is published.
  • The structure of the data.
  • The channels through which the data is available.

_items.title: Social requirements
_items.body:
For data use to be sustainable, it is important to have an engaged community of users. The best datasets have:

  • Active support channels.
  • Discussion groups and forums.
  • Published how-to guides on working with the data.

title: Common data structures
body: Not all data can be appropriately expressed as a spreadsheet. Different file formats may have to be considered. There are three key structures to be aware of: tabular, hierarchical and network.
instruction: Click the forward arrow to see more

_items.title: Tabular
_items.body:
The most common structure for data is tabular. Data is organised into rows and columns listing sequential values, such as expenditure.

If the data is based on separate entries that are not linked to each other then a tabular file structure in a format such as CSV is ideal. An example of appropriate tabular data is the Tanzania Data Portal's Number of Teachers in Secondary Schools.

Take me to Tanzania Data Portal

_items.title: Hierarchical
_items.body:
Hierarchical data shows the relationships between data points, such as a family tree or municipalities in each country. If the dataset depends on the relationship between data points and follows a structure in which data points are linked in vertical ‘trees’, a hierarchical data structure in a format such as JSON is ideal. An example of appropriate hierarchical data is this JSON file for Seirra Leone's Forestry Cover

Take me to the Sierra Leone Forestry Data

_items.title: Network
_items.body:
Network structured data allows relationships to exist between any combination of elements in any direction.

A good example of a network data structure are social networks. Think of your network of friends and their friends on Facebook; consider first, second and third degree contacts on LinkedIn.

The web is another example of a network data structure, where web pages link to any number of other pages in any direction.

title: Finding open data in the right formats
displayTitle: Finding open data in the right formats
body:
As a user of open data, it is important to understand how publishers are delivering different formats to you for reuse.

Not all data is suitable for download either because it is too large, too regularly updated or too complex to expose as static files. Some data may need to be split into smaller parts. Other data may need to be published as live feeds to make sure it stays up to date.

_items.title: Downloadable open data
_items.body:
Tabular data is the most suited for download. This is why most government open data portals are predominantly tabular data. However managing millions of rows of data may require other considerations:

  • Should the data be split into smaller datasets?
  • How often should the data be updated?
  • How will changes in the way you publish affect the previous releases?

_items.title: Live data and data feeds
_items.body:
Some data is not suitable to be made available as a downloadable file.

Much of this data is updated so regularly that the file downloads would be too large for most users. This type of open data structure may be made available by a machine interface, also know as an API.

There are many services that make machine interfaces available over the web. These services can be directly integrated into other web applications. For an example of an open data API, look at the Open Data for Africa example.
Take me to Open Data for Africa API

title: Unlocking data on the web
body:
We briefly mentioned before that a lot of open data can be simply downloaded through clicking buttons. However there are still challenges in finding this data in the first place, or once you do, getting hold of it if there isn't a download button.

This session unlocks the secrets of obtaining and preparing data that is available on the web.
instruction: Click below to explore each of the tools to unlock data that is on the web.

_items.title: Downloadable data
_items.body:
Many suppliers are helpful and give you human readable download links in order to obtain their data.

Explore the links below to discover more:

  • data.gov.uk - Land Registry Monthly Property Transaction Data
  • Nike - Manufacturing Map
  • New York City Open Data

_items.title: Power search for data
_items.body:
Many search engines, including google, give you the ability to use advanced searches and prefixs in order to dig out data.

Try some of the following search prefixes in google to see what you can find:

filetype:

Search for specific file types only, e.g. (xls) (example)

site:

Search with a specific domain or site only (example)

related:

Search for content related to a known page (example)

link:

List only pages that link to the one given (example)

_items.title: Aggregators and portals
_items.body:
Aggregates and portals bring together data from accross the web and expose through their own service. This creates and easy and consistant way to find and download data.

Explore the links below to find out more:

enigma.io

Powerful open data searching for structured data

Transport API

All UK transport data, in one place, with one API.

_items.title: Web scraping
_items.body:
If you can't simply download data in a usable format, you may need to scrape it. Helpfully there are now many tools that help us achieve this easily:

pdftables.com

Upload a PDF, download data, simple.

magic.import.io

Extract data from web pages in a click.

title: How to find hidden data
body:
From data we gain information, from information we gain knowledge and insight.

Please note that just because you can extract hidden data, it does not make this data open. You should always check the terms of use and licences of the website before gathering or using data for any purpose. For further details on licensing, please refer back to module 4 of this course.

_items.title: Adding extensions
_items.body:
Some websites have been built to offer a way to extract data by adding an extension to the URL of the web page you are viewing. For such websites, usually maintained by organisations who also publish downloadable open data, adding the correct extension will trigger a download of that page in a data format, as opposed to a browser format.

A good example of this is the UK Government website (gov.uk) which provides any page in a data format simply by adding the relevant extension like “.json”, for example www.gov.uk/browse/business.json.

Try it with the UK Trade data by viewing the following page and then adding “.json” to get the data.
Take me to the UK gov trade tariff

To view the data in a more human readable form copy it into jsonlint.io

_items.title: Data feeds
_items.body:
Many websites provide links to data syndication feeds that can be subscribed to.

These feeds may be RSS feeds, Twitter alert feeds or other less common types. Feeds can be used to get raw data about a broad selection of content.

For an example of a raw data feed, look at the BBC news feed in XML.
Why not try out the news feeds from the BBC in XML.

Now you can use a free online tool to make that data easier to use
Go to codebeautify and enter the BBC feed URL under 'Load URL'

or get alerts for flooding from your nearest river (UK only).
Take me to river level guages

_items.title: Extracting embedded data
_items.body:
Many websites dynamically load data, saving web browsers time loading endless pages. This is especially the case with embedded weather widgets and shopping websites where templates are filled with data once they are loaded.

As a nice aside, this means that your web browser has loaded structured data onto your computer. All we have to do is access it directly so it can be used.

Why not check out the ODI's experimental 'Hidden Data Extractor' tool to find if your website have data embedded within them?

Take me to ODI Hidden Data Extractor

_items.title: APIs or machine-readable interfaces
_items.body:
Some websites or web services will expose a machine-readable interface, or API, for querying and accessing their data.

Examples of services that have APIs include: Open Corporates (open), OpenSteetMap (open), Twitter (not completely open), Flickr (some content open), LinkedIn (not open).

Most of these services use a web based API and allow addition of extensions (try “.json” on OpenCorporates). Although this API looks the same as the earlier example in this section, it's formal status as an API provides a guarantee that the service will be available.

title: Key features of open data platforms
displayTitle: Key features of open data platforms
body: Open data platforms make open data discoverable and usable in a consistent way.
instruction: Click the forward arrow for more.Select the ‘+’ sign to explore further, then swipe the image to see more.

_items.title: Discoverable data
_items.body:
Open data platforms promote open data to users. Platforms are designed to allow users to quickly find and reuse relevant open data.

Platforms are search-optimised to make it easier to find relevant resources. Platforms also provide data feeds that can be discovered and indexed in systems across the web.

The data feeds of open data platforms allow search engines like Enigma.io to to index open data and make it easier to find.
Discover more at enigma.io

_items.title: Consistent user experience
_items.body:
There are a limited number of open data platforms, which means you don’t need to know lots of different technologies to discover large amounts of open data.

Open data platforms are designed with the user in mind. The platform layout and design makes it easy to discover data.

For examples of sites using open data platforms, look at: opendata.go.ke/, data.gov.bf and data.ug/

Note that many governments use a standard naming convention for the web address of the data platform, so a simple starting point for finding open data for a country is to enter data.gov.[country top-level domain].

_items.title: Consistent access to data
_items.body:
The development of open standards by the community on the web has led to consistent Application Programming Interfaces (APIs) for discovering, accessing and using data.

The limited number of open data platforms and the consistent features of their user interfaces make it simple for people to use the different features while feeling comfortable with the software.

The platforms also have similar structures and formats for exposing metadata as well as the data itself.

title: Open data platform design approaches
body: Platforms provide different approaches to publishing and exposing open data. Discover the different approaches below:

_items.title: Data catalogs
_items.body:
An open data catalog is a platform that lists datasets on the web. Data catalogs are like directories. They know what open data exists, what it is about, where it is and how to get hold of it.

An open data catalog links users to data that is located somewhere else on the web. They provide a consistent way of locating a diverse set of data that is widely scattered.

The CKAN platform, used by sites like Uganda's Open Data Portal (Take me to Uganda CKAN portal), Edo State, Nigeria (Take me to the Edo State CKAN portal) and Open Data for Africa (Take me to Africa open data CKAN portal), can be used as a data catalog.

CKAN provides simple, easy to use data management functionality, including data hosting. This ensures that the technical knowledge and effort required to publish open data is kept to a minimum.

_items.title: Data management
_items.body:
Open data management platforms can also play an active role in the way a publisher manages and maintains a dataset. Publishers can update data directly in the platform and regularly provide updates.

For users, searching for and manipulating open data without having to download it can make reusing it a lot easier.

For publishers however, there is a much greater challenge in structuring and formatting data for the platform. This can be overcome if the publisher also uses the publishing platform to access the data.

The Socrtata platform, used by the Kenya open data portal (Take me to Kenya open data portal), and the Open Data Soft platform used by the city of Issy-les-Moulineaux in France (Take me to Issy open data portal) are good examples of data management platforms.

_items.title: Comparison
_items.body:
Data catalogs provide:

  • Federated search across a wide domain.
  • Mechanisms for discovery.
  • Key metadata relating to licence and how up to date data is.

    • Data management platforms provide:

    • Authoritative sources for data.
    • Increased data quality.
    • Ability to search and manipulate data.

    The distinctions between data management platforms and data catalogs can also vary between providers. Take me to comparative analysis of data platforms

title: Hands-on with publishing platforms
body:
This hands-on exercise gives you the opportunity to explore a variety of the available open data platforms.

Explore each section to discover how to get starded on each platform.

_items.title: CKAN
_items.body: CKAN is the catalog for open data. It simplfies the process of publishing open data. A link will be available on the day of the course for you to try. You can also get started quickly with CKAN by launching your own instace in Amazon Web Services (AWS) by following this link.

_items.title: OpenDataSoft
_items.body:
OpenDataSoft is a fully fledged enterprise data management solution that has a focus on open data. The platform is developed in France and as such has many multi-language users including TGV.

Registration requires invitation from course leader and accounts stay active for around 2-3 months before being account and related datasets are removed.

Click here to begin your registration.

Many thanks go to OpenDataSoft for hosting the ODI Training instance.

_items.title: Socrata
_items.body:
Socrata is also a fully fledged enterprise data management solution which also handles 5-star linked data. This platform is developed in Seattle and has high profile customers including NASA.

Registration requires invitation from course leader and accounts stay active for around 2-3 months before being account and related datasets are removed.

Click here to begin your registration.

Many thanks go to Socrata for hosting the ODI Training instance.

_items.title: Github data publisher
_items.body:
Github data publisher is an Open Data Institute experiment in using the Github software version control system to manage data.

Using this service requires a github account which has been enabled for web hosting (How-To Guide here

Click hereto access the Git Data Publisher.

title: Open Data in Practice Day 1 - Practical Publication
displayTitle: Open Data in Practice Day 1 - Practical Publication
body: This introductory course aims to get you up to speed with latest developments in open data and its significance. It is designed to enable anyone to get started with discovering and using open data and understand the skills and processes required to make it work for you and your organisation.
